docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The most glaring omission in the Cheney-Lieberman debate was the failure of either to address the question of universal health coverage for all the American people under a government-run, single-payer plan (front page, Oct. 6).

headline.main: The Race for No. 2: A Debate With a Difference

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that requires the state to provide New Yorkers with extensive information about malpractice judgments and disciplinary actions against doctors practicing in the state. The new law requires the New York State Department of Health to post such information on the Internet and to make it available through a toll-free telephone number.

headline.main: Pataki Orders State Records On Doctors To Be Posted

docs.abstract: New York Governor George E Pataki signs legislation requiring state to provide residents with extensive information about malpractice judgments against doctors practicing in New York; State Department of Health will be required to post information on Internet and make it available through toll-free telephone number; hailed by Pataki as victory for consumers, law is effective immediately (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After keeping his Democratic opponent, Jon S. Corzine, on the defensive for weeks, Representative Bob Franks, the Republican candidate for Senate, suddenly found himself dealing with problems of his own making today. First, Mr. Franks had to admit he had misspoken when he claimed he had never taken any campaign contributions from the National Rifle Association. Then his latest criticism of Mr. Corzine -- calling him anti-labor, despite his support from much of the New Jersey labor movement -- seemed to backfire.

headline.main: Franks Defends Claims on N.R.A. and Labor Support

docs.abstract: Republican Senatorial candidate from NJ Representative Bob Franks is forced to retract statement about never having taken campaign contributions from National Rifle Association when in fact he did receive money in 1986 and 1987; Franks calls it oversight, and contends NRA worked hard to defeat him when he ran for Congress in 1992; additionally, Franks has referred to opponent Jon Corzine as anti-labor because of situation at Goldman, Sachs in which cafeteria workers attempted to organize, but it appears this happened after Corzine has retired from Goldman and in fact had expressed support for efforts to organize; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Sept. 30 front-page article reports that up to half of the 538,000 children in Child Health Plus in New York State may be inappropriately enrolled in the program when in fact they are eligible for Medicaid. Switching children between programs threatens their health care access. There must be a transition that preserves continuity of care.
docs.abstract: Letter by Dennis Johnson of Children's Health Fund on report that up to half of children in New York's Child Health Plus should be enrolled in Medicaid instead; warns that switching children between programs threatens health care access

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of ailing uranium miners would become eligible for additional benefits while sick workers from weapons plants would receive compensation for work-related illnesses for the first time under a deal reached today by House and Senate negotiators. The cost was estimated at almost $1 billion over the first five years, Congressional aides said.

headline.main: Deal Reached on Aid for Uranium Miners

docs.abstract: House and Senate negotiators reach agreement under which thousands of ailing uranium miners would become eligible for additional benefits while sick workers from weapons plants would receive compensation for work-related illnesses for first time (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the vice-presidential debate last night in Danville, Ky., between Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and Dick Cheney, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Bernard Shaw of CNN. The Projected Budget Surplus MR. SHAW Senator, few hard-working Americans would base their well-being on bonuses they hope to get five or 10 years from now. Why do you and you, Secretary Cheney, predict surpluses you cannot possibly guarantee to pay for your proposed programs?

docs.lead_paragraph: REBECCA LIEBERMAN, the famous man's daughter and the newest $75,000-a-year employee at the New York City Board of Education, had been thinking about doing a book about fathers and daughters. This is the kind of concept that could become a best-seller when you're the eldest daughter of the first Jewish candidate for vice president from a major party. But Ms. Lieberman, devoted daughter though she is, gave up the idea after two interviews with potential subjects. ''Part of it was, I thought it would be hard to make it interesting,'' she confided in her bubbly, girl-next-door manner. ''People really only said positive things: 'Daddy was so great. He had incredible integrity. Such a sweet man.' ''

headline.main: Of Family Names, Lucky Breaks and Politics

docs.abstract: Public Lives column profiles Rebecca Lieberman, daughter of Sen Joseph I Lieberman; she discusses her working for her father's Vice Presidential candidacy and being hired as fund raiser for New York City Board of Education; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Americans look back on this presidential campaign, they may remember it as the moment in which the specter of International Communism was replaced by the horror of ''fuzzy math.'' ''He loves to talk about numbers,'' cried George W. Bush at a post-debate rally, where he laced into Al Gore as -- well, a person who loves to talk about numbers. That was the cue for the crowd to chant: ''No fuzzy math! No fuzzy math!''
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column holds that Vice Pres Gore's lapses into semi-fiction have come to assume enormous import in presidential race; maintains that polls show that Americans agree with his positions on most issues, but they appear to be wrestling with question of whether they can bear to have him around for four long years (M)
docs.snippet: When Americans look back on this presidential campaign, they may remember it as the moment in which the specter of International Communism was replaced by the horror of ''fuzzy math.''    ''He loves to talk about numbers,'' cried George W. Bush at a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania has one of the nation's largest state-run drug-subsidy programs for its older low-income residents. So it seemed natural for Gov. George W. Bush to choose it last month as the place to announce his program to help states ease drug costs for those on Medicare. The thrust of Mr. Bush's proposal is to let managed care companies compete for patients with Medicare, the federal health insurance program for people 65 or older. Since the plan would not take effect for at least four years, Mr. Bush has proposed an interim step of allocating $48 billion -- $12 billion a year -- to subsidize state prescription drug plans.

headline.main: States' Drug Subsidy Programs Have Troubles of Their Own

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush chose Pennsylvania as place to announce his program to help states ease drug costs for those on Medicare; Pennsylvania and many other states are struggling with rising prescription drug costs and tight eligibility requirements that are excluding many older residents; how effective Bush's proposed federal subsidies would be in solving problems is in dispute (M)
